Problem:
Consider the complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \) where \\( \omega \\) is a real constant and \\( i \\) is the imaginary unit. This function describes an oscillatory system in the complex plane. We examine the effects of the Laplace transformation \\( \mathcal{L} \\) on this system and its implications on the causal inference.

If at a specific time \\( t_1 \\), a damping factor \\( e^{-\alpha t} \\) with \\( \alpha > 0 \\) is introduced as an intervention, does this affect the outcome of the Laplace transform at time T, when \\( T > t_1 \\)?
Explanation: The introduction of a damping factor \\( e^{-\alpha t} \\) modifies the system to \\( z(t) = e^{-(\alpha - i\omega)t} \\). Therefore, the Laplace transform changes to \\( \mathcal{L} \{ z(t) \} (s) = \frac{1}{s + \alpha - i\omega} \\). This new form is a direct consequence of the intervention, altering both the decay rate and the complex frequency component of the system.
